channel.title: Files
channel.description:
http://pastebin.com/m655d0009
why is it when I select a file with the chooser and I do listFiles() it returns only the directories not the filenames in the folders
like if I select c:\ and I turn c:\ into a file object I want to do file.list() and get files in c:\.
yes I used netbeans shits do soon and I have a lot of work to do.

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @VB7_Rocks VB7 Rocks
item.description:
@VB7_Rocks wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:19, topic:212812”][quote author=VB7 Rocks link=topic=280247.msg2284215#msg2284215 date=1213838277]

Actually, JLayer is quite nice for playing MP3s. Not sure how old it is, though.

Except I can’t get it to work in vista
[/quote]I always that it was platform-independent, and still believe it is. It definitely should work with Windows Vista. So my assumption is that you are using it incorrectly.[/quote]

No, it’s the same package/library/whatever that is used in the moparscape 3 client, which coincidentally, the sound doesn’t work on vista either.

Not to mention I used their sample program exactly as it said, and it didn’t work on vista. Works fine on XP though. It might be just me, but can anyone else with vista confirm whether JLayer works under vista?

I’m really hoping it’s not just a problem with my computer

Read full topic

[/quote]

Except I can’t get it to work in vista :([/quote]I always that it was platform-independent, and still believe it is. It definitely should work with Windows Vista. So my assumption is that you are using it incorrectly.

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @BAsh BAsh
item.description:
@BAsh wrote:

I really hate the fact that Sun has completely neglected reading and writing media. Sure you can do a lot with images but does anybody know how to read and write music and video without installing another package which is completely outdated? All I can find are the remnants of J3D and a few look a likes but none are something you would want to work with.

Read full topic

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

[quote=“chrisn2323, post:10, topic:212812”]Yeah its in the code. It’s supposed to print filenames but it prints the names of folders.

What seems to happen is if I select a folder such as “C:\My Music\50 Cent” It won’t show the files in “50 Cent” but all the folders in “My Music”.[/quote]The problem is, getCurrentDirectory() of the JFileChooser class returns the directly you last OPENED. If you select it and then click OK, then you will get the LAST directory you opened. So instead of doing that, simply use JFileChooser.getSelectedFile() and then check if it is a directory by File.isDirectory().

Read full topic

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

Yeah its in the code. It’s supposed to print filenames but it prints the names of folders.

What seems to happen is if I select a folder such as “C:\My Music\50 Cent” It won’t show the files in “50 Cent” but all the folders in “My Music”.

Read full topic

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @TeleNubby TeleNubby
item.description:
@TeleNubby wrote:

http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/io/File.html#listFiles():

If this abstract pathname does not denote a directory, then this method returns null.

Apparently JFileChooser.getCurrentDirectory() is returning null, or the pathname is not a directory. At least that is the only thing I see as of right now. Have you tried debugging the problem a little further? Try printing out the name of the directory and see if it is truely null or not, or if it is even the right directory. Report back here.

Read full topic

item.title: Files
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“TeleNubby, post:7, topic:212812”]If YOU’RE the one who programmed it, how did you not notice the:

chooser.setFileSelectionMode(JFileChooser.DIRECTORIES_ONLY); [/quote]
I am pretty sure that would only affect the files you see in the JFileChooser

not when you do file.list();

Read full topic
